Good man!

World-Honored One!

If one can skillfully make the unsurpassed great vow, this is called the wise ones.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas always closely attend to the Buddha, Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, good and virtuous friends, make offerings and pay respects to them, inquire about the profound Dharma, uphold it without fail, and make this vow:
'I now draw near to the Buddhas, the Hearers, the Solitary Sages, and good friends. Even if I undergo great suffering for immeasurable eons, I will not give rise to a mind of turning back from Bodhi!
If sentient beings, with evil minds, beat, scold, or insult my body, I wish that because of this, I will increase my compassionate mind even more and not give rise to evil thoughts!
I vow that in my future lives, wherever I am born, I will not receive a female body, a body lacking faculties, a body with two faculties, or the body of a slave!
I also vow to enable my body to have the power of self-mastery to serve others, and not allow others to have the power of self-mastery to command me!

I vow that my body will be endowed with all faculties, will stay far away from bad friends, will not be born in evil countries or border regions, will always be born in a prominent family, will have exceptional appearance and strength, and will have mastery over wealth and treasures!
I wish to obtain a good and independent mind, and a courageous and healthy mind!
Whatever I say, may the listeners joyfully accept it, and may I be free from all obstacles!
They are not negligent, free from all evil deeds of body, speech, and mind, and always greatly benefit sentient beings.
For the sake of benefiting sentient beings, they do not crave for their own lives, and do not create evil karma for the sake of their own lives.
When benefiting sentient beings, they do not seek rewards for their kindness.
They always delight in upholding the twelve divisions of the scriptures. Having upheld them themselves, they teach others.
They are able to destroy the evil views and evil karma of sentient beings, and are invincible to all worldly matters.
Having attained victory, they further teach others.

They skillfully treat the serious illnesses of the bodies and minds of sentient beings. Seeing those who are separated and broken, they are able to reconcile them. Seeing those who are frightened, they provide protection. Having provided protection, they expound various teachings, causing those who hear to subdue their minds.
Seeing the hungry, they give their bodies to satisfy them, wishing that they do not give rise to greedy and evil thoughts.
When they are being eaten, it is as if they were eating grass and trees.
Always delighting in making offerings to teachers, elders, parents, good friends, and virtuous elders, and treating enemies and friends with an impartial mind!
Always cultivating the six recollections, the notion of non-self, and the twelve links of dependent origination!
In places where there are no Three Jewels, delighting in tranquility, cultivating compassion and kindness!
If all sentient beings see my body, hear or touch it, they will be far removed from afflictions!'
Although the Bodhisattva knows that apart from enlightenment, he does not seek other fruits, he seeks for the sake of sentient beings in order to greatly benefit them.
Good man!
If a Bodhisattva can make such a vow, know that this person is the unsurpassed Dharma-wealth elder, the seeker of the Dharma-king who has not yet attained the Dharma-king.
Good man!

There are also three things:
First, when suffering for others, the mind does not give rise to regret; second, being endowed with subtle, unsurpassed wisdom; third, when possessing wholesome dharmas, not giving rise to arrogance.
There are also three things:

First, experiencing the suffering of hell for the sake of sentient beings as if it were the bliss of the third dhyÄna; second, not giving rise to jealousy when seeing others gain benefits; third, the wholesome actions one performs are not for the sake of birth and death.
There are also three things:

First, seeing others suffer as if it were no different from one's own; second, all the wholesome practices one cultivates are for the sake of sentient beings; third, skillfully employing skillful means to enable them to be free from suffering.
There are also three things:

First, regarding the pleasures of birth and death as a great poisonous snake; second, delighting in birth and death to benefit sentient beings; third, contemplating the many merits of the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.
There are three more things:
First, giving up one's body; second, giving up one's life; third, giving up wealth;
Giving up these three things is all for the sake of sentient beings.
There are three more things:
First, being insatiable in learning; second, being able to endure all evils; third, teaching others to cultivate patience.
There are three more things:
First, reflecting on one's own faults; second, skillfully concealing the faults of others; third, delighting in cultivating loving-kindness.
There are three more things:
First, sincerely upholding the precepts; second, using the four means of embracing to gather in sentient beings; third, speaking gently and not coarsely.
First, they are able to give the great Dharma; second, they are able to give great wealth; third, they encourage sentient beings to practice through these two kinds of giving.
There are also three things:

First, they always teach and transform sentient beings with the Great Vehicle; second, they always cultivate advancing and superior practices; third, they do not give rise to contempt for any sentient being.
There are also three things:

First, although they are still subject to afflictions, they are able to endure them; second, they know the faults of afflictions and enjoy not being weary of them; third, they are able to destroy others' bonds by themselves being subject to afflictions.
There are also three things:

First, they rejoice as if it were their own when they see others gaining benefits; second, they do not enjoy receiving comfort and happiness alone; third, they do not give rise to a sense of satisfaction with the inferior vehicle.
There are also three things:

First, hearing about the bodhisattvas' ascetic practices, they are not afraid; second, seeing those who seek, they never say there is none; third, they never give rise to the thought that they surpass all others.
Good man!

Chapter 8: The Chapter on the Names and Meanings of Bodhisattvas, the Sutra on UpÄsaka Precepts, the Chapter on the Names and Meanings of Bodhisattvas. SubhÅ«ti said:

As the Buddha has said, there are two kinds of bodhisattvas:
First, nominally bodhisattvas, and second, truly meaningful bodhisattvas.
What are called nominally bodhisattvas?
Good man!

If sentient beings have already given rise to the bodhi mind, they enjoy receiving external techniques and their scriptures, reciting and reading them, and then using these teachings to transform sentient beings, killing for their own lives;

They give rise to a sense of self-contempt towards their own bodies, thinking that they cannot attain supreme enlightenment, and they give rise to a sense of fear towards afflictions, and also do not diligently cultivate the means to destroy bonds;
They always give rise to stinginess, jealousy, and an angry mind, associate with bad friends, are lazy and distracted, and delight in dwelling in ignorance;

They do not believe in the six perfections, do not delight in cultivating blessings, do not contemplate birth and death, and always delight in accepting and upholding the evil words of others. This is called a nominally named bodhisattva.

Although they have a little wholesome mind, it is not firm. For the sake of the five desires and pleasures, they create various evils. Relying on form, life, and wealth, they give rise to great arrogance. Their actions are upside-down and cannot benefit others.

They accept, uphold, recite, copy, and contemplate the meaning.
For the sake of the Dharma, they do not spare their lives, wives, children, or wealth. Their minds are firm.

Diligent in cultivation and practice, despising afflictions, causing those afflictions to be unable to act freely;

They use the four means of attraction to gather in sentient beings, and because they understand worldly truth, they speak in accordance with the beings;
When sentient beings are suffering, their minds are unmoved like Mount Sumeru. Although they see sentient beings committing many evil deeds, they never forget those with even a little goodness;

They do not give rise to doubts towards the Three Jewels, and delight in making offerings. If they have little wealth, they first give to the poor and then to the field of merit. They first help the poor and then the wealthy;
They delight in praising others' goodness and opening the door to nirvana for them;
They wish to teach others their skills, and upon seeing others surpass themselves, they give rise to a joyful mind;

Not thinking of benefiting oneself, always thinking of benefiting others, the good deeds done by body, speech, and mind are never done for oneself, but always for others. This is called a bodhisattva of true meaning.
Good man!
There are two kinds of bodhisattvas:
First, the lay bodhisattva; second, the ordained bodhisattva.
The ordained bodhisattva is a bodhisattva of true meaning, and this is not difficult;
The lay bodhisattva is more difficult.
Why is this?
Because the lay person is bound by many evil conditions.

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cultivate ascetic practices, they first admonish their own minds. Good man!
I recall that in the past, when I was practicing the bodhisattva path, I first received the practice of austerities from non-Buddhist paths and sincerely practiced them with an unwavering mind.

I used cow dung and cow urine as medicine for illnesses.
In the height of summer, I scorched my body with the five heats;
In the first month of winter, I wrapped my body in ice and snow.

I also practiced eating grass, eating roots, eating stems, eating leaves, eating fruits, eating earth, and eating wind. When I practiced such austerities, neither my own body nor others' bodies benefited at all.
Even so, my mind was still unwavering, surpassing all the austerities of non-Buddhists.
Good man!
In the past, I gave up my life for four reasons:

First, to destroy the afflictions of sentient beings; second, to enable sentient beings to experience peace and happiness; third, to eliminate one's own attachment to the body; fourth, to repay the kindness of one's parents in giving birth and raising.
If a bodhisattva can disregard life and limb, he will certainly know that this is a bodhisattva of true meaning.
Good man!
In the past, for the sake of the true Dharma, I gouged out my body to make three thousand six hundred lamps.

At that time, I was still fully endowed with afflictions, and my body truly felt pain. But for the sake of sentient beings to be liberated, I encouraged my mind to be firm and did not give rise to retrogression.

At that time, I immediately attained the perfection of three things: first, I was ultimately without retrogression; second, I became a bodhisattva of true meaning; third, I was called inconceivable. This is called the inconceivability of the bodhisattva.
Moreover, in the past for the sake of the true Dharma, I endured the suffering of a thousand wounds on my body for one eon.

At that time, fully endowed with all afflictions, my body truly experienced suffering. For the sake of liberating sentient beings, I encouraged my mind to be firm and did not give rise to retrogression. This is called the inconceivability of the bodhisattva.
Moreover, in the past for the sake of a single dove, I abandoned this body.

At that time, fully endowed with all afflictions, my body truly experienced suffering. For the sake of liberating sentient beings, I encouraged my mind to be firm and did not give rise to retrogression. This is called the inconceivability of the bodhisattva.
Good man!
All evil friends and afflictive karmas are companions who adorn the bodhisattva path.
Why is it so?

All ordinary beings lack wisdom and right mindfulness, so they take afflictions as their enemies. Bodhisattvas are replete with wisdom and right mindfulness, so they take afflictions as their companions on the path;
Evil friends and karma are also like this.
Good man!
Abandoning afflictions, one will never again receive a body of evil existence.
Therefore, although bodhisattvas manifest evil karma, it is not actually created by evil of body, speech, or mind. It is the power of their vows.
By the power of this vow, they take on the body of a vicious beast, in order to tame those animals.

Having already taken on the body of an animal, bodhisattvas are well-versed in human language, the language of Dharma, truth, non-harsh language, and non-meaningless language. Why is this?

Bodhisattvas are not like this. When transforming sentient beings, they have no coarse and evil speech, angry speech, or frivolous speech. They only have gentle speech and truthful speech. When bodhisattvas teach and transform the blind, deaf, mute, and foolish, and the evil beings in the borderlands, their minds are without weariness. This is called the inconceivability of the bodhisattva.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas have four inconceivabilities:

First, they are able to give to others the things they cherish; second, they are able to endure evil things while possessing various afflictions; third, they are able to reconcile and unite those who are divided; fourth, when facing evil at the time of death, they turn it into the Dharma.
These are called the four inconceivabilities of the bodhisattva.
There are also three inconceivable things:
First, reprimanding all afflictions; second, dwelling amidst afflictions without abandoning them; third, although possessing afflictions and afflictive karma, not being heedless.
These are called the three inconceivable things of the bodhisattvas.
There are also three inconceivable things:
First, when one first wishes to give, joy arises in the mind; second, when giving, one does not seek rewards for others; third, after giving, the mind is joyful and does not give rise to regret.
These are called the three inconceivable things of the bodhisattvas.

Good man!
There are two kinds of bodhisattvas:
First, the lay bodhisattva; second, the renunciant bodhisattva.
It is not difficult for the renunciant bodhisattva to do such things;
It is difficult for the lay bodhisattva to do such things.
Why is it so?
Because householders are often entangled in many evil conditions.
